poem:
**Wilhelmina's Quiet Resilience**  

In Sumatra's shadowed hold,  
a tempest brewed,  
Wilhelmina, cast in time's fierce fold,  
nursed wounds anew.  

From the whispers of oaks,  
skies in scars anew,  
Her hands, tender guides,  
where healing rivers flowed.  

94 years a testament,  
to battles unseen,  
in silence, she reshaped the world,  
beyond the screens.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Wilhelmina Tempest obituary My stepmother, Wilhelmina Tempest, who has died aged 94, was one of the last survivors of wartime Japanese internment camps. She then retrained as a nurse, going to Britain to pursue an interest in burn injuries and plastic surgery. Her grandfather was a Dutch protestant missionary in West Papua. When the second world war reached Sumatra (then a Dutch colony) in 1942, her father, Willem van Hasselt, was the headteacher of a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
